transcripts.text: ISIS had created their own prisons.  They took a soccer stadium and essentially turned the kind of subterranean level into its main prison.  I visited it.  It's just an empty stadium now.  There's nobody there guarding it.  So I went inside.  It felt haunted, you know.  Raqqa was the capital of the Islamic State and the stadium was its central prison.  I met a guy who I'll call Zain, it's not his real name, but he had been a member of the Free Syrian Army years before and was imprisoned in the black stadium.  He took me and showed me around the prison.  So it was the first time he had been back since he himself was imprisoned there.  He had been accused of killing an ISIS member and they came to his house one night and took him.

Hmm.  They took us by force and threw bullets at us.  And they brought me here.  To the last unit.  I was in the second unit.  We don't know what the situation was outside.  We only know that it was dark from day to night, because it was dark, and only the light was on.  They entered us, they let us sleep, but someone woke us up in the morning.
There's rooms that are pitch black, you know, cells that you can barely long enough to lay down in.
Small rooms, toilet in it.  I've heard people talk about being hung by handcuffs up on these.

He said sometimes they would come and take people from a cell and they would never know where they were going or if they were coming back.  He showed us the interrogation rooms.  When he was interrogated, he was taken there blindfolded.

These are the dogs that they were beating us with.  We used to wash our hands because they didn't have mercy or compassion.  In this way, every person, if he doesn't do anything, wants to speak.  How long do they keep you like this?  Maybe a day, maybe three hours, maybe four hours.
But I recommend that they keep him for two days.  I mean, is your foot on the ground or what?
But my toes are the ones that are cut.

But the world is different.  If you come, say, half an hour, an hour, an hour or two, you confess about everything.  They confess about what they want with it.  They take it and they cut it.  And they do something that I didn't do.  I sat with people.  Something that I didn't do.
It's Arabic words, but they're not written in Arabic.  It was written by a foreigner, probably.

One of the things that surprised me about the prison was the writing on the walls was very pro-ISIS.  So this is prisoners writing.  There were almost kind of childish drawings of like a suicide belt or slogans like martyrdom or victory.  Zain described to me that, you know, they would be put through these kind of indoctrination courses while they were in the prison, both on the ISIS kind of religious ideology, but also in battle tactics.  They would watch battle videos over and over again.  The people that got out, got out by convincing their captors that they were true believers, which also is what Zayn described to me, that he just, you know, tried to convince them that he was one of them.  You know, they're tortured to such a degree that they will go into this kind of extra, you know, mode of trying to zealously kind of convince them that what they're saying is true.  The trick is not confessing, it's convincing them that your confession is genuine.

There are people, I know them, they're from the same prison, they're with him.  They fought, then they killed?  I only know that there's more than one person I know, and they call him a traitor.  They have a simple reason, or they don't care about him.
After having shown me the prison, he talked about how he used to come there as a kid.  They would hold weddings in the area that was now a prison.
